articles.title: How flies grow their gyroscopes: Study reveals how flight stabilizers take shape
articles.description: A team from the Institute for Neurosciences (IN), a joint center of the Spanish National Research Council (CSIC) and the Miguel Hernández University (UMH) in Elche, has revealed how a structure essential for fly flight, the haltere, is formed. This small organ, located behind the main wings, functions as a biological gyroscope that helps the insect stay stable in the air.
articles.content:
This article has been reviewed according to Science X's editorial process and policies . Editors have highlighted the following attributes while ensuring the content's credibility:

articles.title: Japan, China trade barbs over fighter jet manoeuvres
articles.description: TOKYO: Beijing condemned on Thursday (Jun 12) what it called "dangerous behaviour" by a Japanese military plane over the Pacific after Tokyo said Chinese fighter jets flew unusually close to its aircraft at the weekend. articles.title: Man, 60s, arrested on suspicion of Annie McCarrick murder
articles.description: A man has been arrested in Dublin for the murder of Annie McCarrick, the 26-year-old American woman who went missing more than 32 years ago.
articles.content:
A man has been arrested in Dublin for the murder of Annie McCarrick, the 26-year-old American woman who went missing more than 32 years ago.
The man, who is in his 60s, was arrested by detectives from Irishtown this morning on suspicion of murder.

articles.title: New large-scale study maps early triggers of Alzheimer’s protein aggregation
articles.description: A new large-scale study has mapped the first molecular events that drive the formation of harmful amyloid protein aggregates found in Alzheimer's disease, pointing towards a new potential therapeutic target.
articles.content:
A new large-scale study has mapped the first molecular events that drive the formation of harmful amyloid protein aggregates found in Alzheimer's disease, pointing towards a new potential therapeutic target.

articles.title: Cate Campbell says lack of pay contributes to swimmers' mental health struggles after Mollie O'Callaghan's teary admission
articles.description: Cate Campbell believes Australia's swimmers would be in a better mental state if they were paid better and could afford time off as a result.
articles.content:
Australian swimming legend Cate Campbell says a lack of funding is partly to blame for many of the sport's stars struggling with mental health issues.

articles.title: Vietnam lawmakers approve merging provinces, slashing nearly 80,000 jobs
articles.description: HANOI: Vietnam's National Assembly on Thursday (Jun 12) approved plans to merge provinces and cities, slashing nearly 80,000 state jobs, as part of major reforms to the communist country's administrative structure.
